metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: interpret spectra and calculate the energy of absorbed or emitted photons: E = hf

quantised_energy_levels.name: Quantised Energy Levels
quantised_energy_levels.correct: Electrons in atoms can only exist in specific, discrete energy levels. No intermediate energies are allowed.

any energy value.error: Classical thinking. Atomic energies are quantised.
any energy value.fix: Only specific orbitals exist. Electrons cannot exist between energy levels.
any energy value.action: Draw an energy level diagram. Notice the gaps between levels.

continuous range.error: Continuous energies would be classical, not quantum.
continuous range.fix: Quantised means discrete, separate values only.
continuous range.action: Look at a hydrogen energy diagram. The levels are distinct lines, not a continuous band.

random energies.error: Energy levels are fixed for each element, not random.
random energies.fix: Each element has a unique, fixed set of energy levels.
random energies.action: Compare hydrogen and helium energy diagrams. Different elements, different levels.

persistent.gap: You're applying classical physics to atomic structure.
persistent.action: Study the Bohr model. Electrons only orbit at specific radii with specific energies.

ground_state.name: Ground State
ground_state.correct: The ground state (n = 1) is the lowest energy level. Electrons naturally fall to this state when possible.

highest energy level.error: Opposite. Ground state is the LOWEST energy.
highest energy level.fix: Ground = bottom. Higher n values mean higher energy.
highest energy level.action: On an energy diagram, ground state is at the bottom.

zero energy.error: Ground state has a specific energy value, not zero.
zero energy.fix: Zero energy is at infinity (ionisation). Ground state is negative (bound).
zero energy.action: Check a hydrogen diagram. Ground state is at -13.6 eV, not 0 eV.

excited state.error: Excited states are ABOVE ground state.
excited state.fix: Excited means higher energy than ground. Ground is the default, lowest state.
excited state.action: Excited = above ground. Ground = lowest possible.

persistent.gap: You're confusing ground and excited states.
persistent.action: Label an energy diagram: ground state at bottom, excited states above.

electron_transition_absorption.name: Electron Transition (Absorption)
electron_transition_absorption.correct: When an electron moves to a HIGHER energy level, it ABSORBS a photon. The photon energy equals the energy difference.

emits a photon.error: Backwards. Moving UP requires absorbing energy.
emits a photon.fix: Up = gain energy = absorb photon. Down = lose energy = emit photon.
emits a photon.action: Draw an upward arrow on an energy diagram. Label it 'absorption'.

loses energy.error: Moving to a higher level means GAINING energy.
loses energy.fix: Higher level = higher energy. Must absorb energy to get there.
loses energy.action: Think of climbing stairs. You need energy to go up.

releases heat.error: Atomic transitions involve photons, not heat.
releases heat.fix: Electrons absorb or emit photons, not thermal energy.
releases heat.action: Energy comes from light (photons), not heat.

persistent.action: Make a two-column table: Absorption (up, photon in) vs Emission (down, photon out).

electron_transition_emission.name: Electron Transition (Emission)
electron_transition_emission.correct: When an electron moves to a LOWER energy level, it EMITS a photon. The photon energy equals the energy difference.

absorbs a photon.fix: Down = lose energy = emit photon. Up = gain energy = absorb photon.
absorbs a photon.action: Draw a downward arrow on an energy diagram. Label it 'emission'.

gains energy.error: Moving to a lower level means LOSING energy.
gains energy.fix: Lower level = lower energy. The lost energy becomes a photon.
gains energy.action: Think of falling. You release energy going down.

no photon involved.error: Photon emission is how atoms lose energy.
no photon involved.fix: The energy difference becomes a photon with E = hf.
no photon involved.action: Conservation of energy: the electron loses energy, the photon carries it away.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how electrons release energy.
persistent.action: Practice: draw 5 emission transitions. For each, calculate the photon energy.

photon_energy_formula.name: Photon Energy Formula
photon_energy_formula.correct: Photon energy is calculated using E = hf or E = hc/λ, where h is Planck's constant.

E = mc².error: That's rest mass energy. Photons have no rest mass.
E = mc².fix: Photons use E = hf or E = hc/λ, not E = mc².
E = mc².action: E = mc² is for matter at rest. E = hf is for photons.

E = ½mv².error: That's kinetic energy of matter. Photons use E = hf.
E = ½mv².fix: Photons don't have mass or velocity in the classical sense.
E = ½mv².action: Photon energy depends on frequency, not mass or speed.

E = hλ.error: Wrong formula. λ should be in the denominator.
E = hλ.fix: E = hc/λ. Higher wavelength = lower energy (inverse).
E = hλ.action: Check: longer wavelength (red) should give lower energy.

persistent.gap: You're confusing photon energy formulas with matter formulas.
persistent.action: Memorise: Photons → E = hf = hc/λ. Matter → KE = ½mv².

energy_difference_calculation.name: Energy Difference Calculation
energy_difference_calculation.correct: The photon energy equals the difference between energy levels: E_photon = E_higher − E_lower.

sum of energy levels.fix: Subtract the lower level from the higher level.
sum of energy levels.action: E_photon = E_final − E_initial (for emission) or E_higher − E_lower.

product of energy levels.error: Energy levels are subtracted, not multiplied.
product of energy levels.fix: ΔE = E₂ − E₁. Subtraction gives the gap between levels.
product of energy levels.action: If levels are 10.2 eV and 12.1 eV, photon energy is 12.1 − 10.2 = 1.9 eV.

ratio of energy levels.fix: ΔE = E_higher − E_lower. No division involved.
ratio of energy levels.action: Practice: given two energy levels, calculate the difference.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how to calculate energy differences.
persistent.action: Work through 5 problems: find photon energy from energy level diagrams.

emission_spectrum_bands.name: Emission Spectrum Features
emission_spectrum_bands.correct: An emission spectrum shows bright coloured lines on a dark background. Each line corresponds to a specific electron transition.

dark lines on bright background.error: That describes an absorption spectrum, not emission.
dark lines on bright background.fix: Emission = bright lines (photons emitted). Absorption = dark lines (photons removed).
dark lines on bright background.action: Emission: atoms emit light at specific wavelengths → bright lines.

continuous rainbow.error: Line spectra have discrete lines, not a continuous band.
continuous rainbow.fix: Quantised energy levels produce discrete wavelengths, not a continuum.
continuous rainbow.action: Look at a hydrogen emission spectrum. You see separate lines, not a rainbow.

single colour.fix: Many possible transitions = many different wavelengths = many lines.
single colour.action: Count the lines in a helium spectrum. Multiple colours from multiple transitions.

persistent.gap: You're not visualising emission spectra correctly.
persistent.action: Search for images of hydrogen and helium emission spectra. Note the bright lines.

absorption_spectrum_bands.name: Absorption Spectrum Features
absorption_spectrum_bands.correct: An absorption spectrum shows dark lines on a continuous bright background. Dark lines appear where photons are absorbed.

bright lines on dark background.error: That describes an emission spectrum, not absorption.
bright lines on dark background.fix: Absorption = dark lines (photons removed). Emission = bright lines (photons added).
bright lines on dark background.action: Absorption: atoms remove light at specific wavelengths → dark lines.

completely dark.error: Only specific wavelengths are absorbed, not all light.
completely dark.fix: Most light passes through. Only photons matching energy gaps are absorbed.
completely dark.action: Absorption removes specific wavelengths, leaving gaps in the spectrum.

random pattern.error: Dark lines appear at specific, predictable wavelengths.
random pattern.fix: Each element absorbs at specific wavelengths determined by its energy levels.
random pattern.action: Absorption lines match emission lines for the same element.

persistent.gap: You're confusing emission and absorption spectra.
persistent.action: Compare side-by-side: emission (bright on dark) vs absorption (dark on bright).

frequency_energy_relationship.name: Frequency-Energy Relationship
frequency_energy_relationship.correct: Photon energy is directly proportional to frequency. Higher frequency means higher energy.

inversely proportional.fix: E and f are in a multiplication relationship, not division.
inversely proportional.action: Double the frequency → double the energy. Direct relationship.

unrelated.error: Frequency and energy are directly linked by E = hf.
unrelated.fix: Planck's equation E = hf explicitly relates them.
unrelated.action: Calculate E for f = 1 × 10¹⁴ Hz and f = 2 × 10¹⁴ Hz. Compare.

exponentially related.error: It's a simple linear relationship, not exponential.
exponentially related.fix: E = hf is linear. Double f means double E.
exponentially related.action: Plot E vs f. You get a straight line through the origin.

persistent.gap: You don't understand E = hf as a proportionality.
persistent.action: Graph E vs f for several photons. Verify the straight-line relationship.

wavelength_energy_relationship.name: Wavelength-Energy Relationship
wavelength_energy_relationship.correct: Photon energy is inversely proportional to wavelength. Longer wavelength means lower energy.

directly proportional.fix: λ is in the denominator. Bigger λ means smaller E.
directly proportional.action: Red light (long λ) has less energy than blue light (short λ).

unrelated.error: Wavelength and energy are inversely linked by E = hc/λ.
unrelated.fix: The formula E = hc/λ shows the inverse relationship.
unrelated.action: Calculate E for λ = 400 nm (violet) and λ = 700 nm (red). Compare.

same value.error: E and λ have different units and values.
same value.action: Check units: E is in Joules or eV, λ is in metres.

persistent.gap: You don't understand inverse proportionality in E = hc/λ.
persistent.action: Calculate E for λ = 100, 200, 400, 800 nm. Watch E decrease as λ increases.

metal_vapour_lamps.name: Metal Vapour Lamps
metal_vapour_lamps.correct: Metal vapour lamps work by exciting gaseous metal atoms, which then emit photons at specific wavelengths as electrons drop to lower energy levels.

thermal radiation.error: Metal vapour lamps produce line spectra, not continuous thermal spectra.
thermal radiation.fix: The light comes from electron transitions, not hot filament radiation.
thermal radiation.action: Sodium lamps produce yellow light at specific wavelengths, not a continuous spectrum.

chemical reactions.error: The light comes from electron transitions, not chemistry.
chemical reactions.fix: Electrons are excited electrically, then emit photons when they fall back down.
chemical reactions.action: The process is physical (electron energy levels), not chemical.

nuclear processes.error: This is atomic physics, not nuclear physics.
nuclear processes.fix: Only electron orbitals are involved, not the nucleus.
nuclear processes.action: Electron transitions are in the eV range. Nuclear changes are in MeV range.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how gas discharge lamps work.
persistent.action: Trace the process: electrical excitation → excited electrons → photon emission → characteristic colour.

element_identification.name: Element Identification from Spectra
element_identification.correct: Each element has a unique emission and absorption spectrum. This spectral fingerprint can identify unknown elements.

all elements have same spectrum.error: Different elements have different energy levels, so different spectra.
all elements have same spectrum.fix: Each element has unique energy level spacing, producing unique line patterns.
all elements have same spectrum.action: Compare hydrogen and helium spectra. Clearly different patterns.

spectra depend on temperature only.error: Line positions depend on the element, not temperature.
spectra depend on temperature only.fix: Temperature affects intensity, but line positions are fixed for each element.
spectra depend on temperature only.action: Heat hydrogen hotter: brighter lines, same wavelengths.

cannot identify elements.error: Spectroscopy is a standard identification technique.
cannot identify elements.fix: Helium was discovered in the Sun by its spectrum before being found on Earth.
cannot identify elements.action: Spectroscopy identifies elements in distant stars. Very reliable.

persistent.gap: You don't see spectra as element fingerprints.
persistent.action: Study 5 different element spectra. Learn to recognise hydrogen and helium by sight.

energy_levels.title: Atomic Energy Levels
energy_levels.instructions: Complete the statements about electron energy levels in atoms.

sentences.text: Electrons in atoms can only exist in {{d1}} energy levels, meaning they cannot have just any energy value. This property is called {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Can electrons exist at any energy, or only certain values?

d2.tooltip: What's the term for having only specific allowed values?

sentences.text: The lowest energy level is called the {{d3}}, labelled n = 1. Energy levels above this are called {{d4}} states.

d3.tooltip: What's the name for the lowest possible energy state?

d4.tooltip: States with more energy than the minimum are called what?

sentences.text: When an electron moves from a lower to a higher energy level, it must {{d5}} a photon. The photon energy must {{d6}} the energy difference between the levels.

d5.tooltip: Moving UP in energy requires gaining energy from where?

d6.tooltip: What's the relationship between photon energy and the energy gap?

photon_energy.title: Calculating Photon Energy
photon_energy.instructions: Complete the statements about photon energy calculations.

sentences.text: The energy of a photon is calculated using E = {{d1}}, where h is {{d2}} and f is the frequency.

d1.tooltip: What formula relates photon energy to frequency?

d2.tooltip: Which constant appears in quantum mechanics equations for photons?

sentences.text: Photon energy is {{d3}} proportional to frequency, meaning higher frequency photons have {{d4}} energy.

d3.tooltip: In E = hf, what happens to E when f increases?

d4.tooltip: E = hf: if f is larger, what happens to E?

sentences.text: The formula E = hc/λ shows that photon energy is {{d5}} proportional to wavelength. Red light with longer wavelength has {{d6}} energy than blue light.

d5.tooltip: λ is in the denominator. What type of proportionality is this?

d6.tooltip: Red light has longer wavelength. Using E = hc/λ, what does that mean for E?

emission_spectra.title: Emission Spectra
emission_spectra.instructions: Complete the statements about emission spectra.

sentences.text: When an electron moves from a higher to a lower energy level, it {{d1}} a photon. This process is called {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Moving DOWN in energy releases energy as what?

d2.tooltip: What's the term for releasing a photon?

sentences.text: An emission spectrum shows {{d3}} lines on a {{d4}} background. Each bright line corresponds to a specific electron transition.

d3.tooltip: Atoms EMIT light. What would that look like against darkness?

d4.tooltip: Between the emission lines, is there light or darkness?

sentences.text: Each element produces a {{d5}} emission spectrum because it has unique {{d6}}. This allows identification of unknown elements.

d5.tooltip: Do different elements have different spectra?

d6.tooltip: What property of atoms determines their spectral lines?

absorption_spectra.title: Absorption Spectra
absorption_spectra.instructions: Complete the statements about absorption spectra.

sentences.text: An absorption spectrum is formed when white light passes through a gas. Atoms {{d1}} photons at specific wavelengths, creating {{d2}} lines in the spectrum.

d1.tooltip: The gas removes certain wavelengths. What happens to those photons?

d2.tooltip: If photons are removed, what appears at those wavelengths?

sentences.text: An absorption spectrum shows {{d3}} lines on a {{d4}} background. This is the opposite appearance of an emission spectrum.

d3.tooltip: Photons are absorbed. What's left at those wavelengths?

d4.tooltip: The background is white light that wasn't absorbed.

sentences.text: The dark lines in an absorption spectrum appear at the {{d5}} wavelengths as the bright lines in that element's emission spectrum. This is because both involve the same {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Absorption and emission involve the same energy gaps.

d6.tooltip: What atomic process produces spectral lines?

energy_levels.title: Energy Level Transitions
energy_levels.instructions: Apply your understanding of energy levels to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A hydrogen atom has an electron in the n = 2 level at 10.2 eV. To reach the n = 4 level at 12.8 eV, the electron must absorb a photon with energy {{d1}}. After absorption, the electron is in an {{d2}} state.

d1.tooltip: What's the difference between 12.8 eV and 10.2 eV?

d2.tooltip: Any state above n = 1 is called what?

sentences.text: Electrons can only exist where their de Broglie wavelength forms a {{d3}} around the nucleus. This requirement explains why energy levels are {{d4}} rather than continuous.

d3.tooltip: What type of wave must fit exactly around the orbital path?

d4.tooltip: Limited to specific values means they are...

sentences.text: When an electron returns to the ground state from n = 3, it releases energy as a photon. The transition from n = 3 to n = 1 releases {{d5}} energy than the transition from n = 3 to n = 2 because the energy {{d6}} is larger.

d5.tooltip: Is the gap from n=3 to n=1 bigger or smaller than n=3 to n=2?

d6.tooltip: Photon energy equals what mathematical operation on the levels?

photon_energy.title: Applying E = hf
photon_energy.instructions: Apply the photon energy formula to calculations and comparisons.

sentences.text: A photon has frequency 5.0 × 10¹⁴ Hz. Using h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s, its energy is approximately {{d1}}. This is in the {{d2}} part of the visible spectrum.

d1.tooltip: Multiply h × f. Watch the exponents.

sentences.text: To convert photon energy from joules to electron-volts, divide by {{d3}}. An energy of 3.2 × 10⁻¹⁹ J equals {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: 1 eV = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ J. To convert J to eV...

sentences.text: Ultraviolet light has {{d5}} frequency than visible light, so UV photons have {{d6}} energy. This explains why UV can cause more damage to skin.

d5.tooltip: UV is beyond violet. Violet has the highest visible frequency.

emission_spectra.title: Interpreting Emission Spectra
emission_spectra.instructions: Apply your understanding of emission spectra to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A sodium vapour lamp produces bright yellow light at approximately 589 nm. This wavelength corresponds to electrons transitioning between {{d1}} energy levels in sodium atoms. The yellow colour indicates photons with energy around {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Does sodium emit at all wavelengths or specific ones?

d2.tooltip: 589 nm visible light has energy in the low eV range.

sentences.text: A gas discharge tube glows with multiple colours because electrons make {{d3}} different transitions, each producing a photon with a {{d4}} wavelength.

d3.tooltip: Can electrons transition between multiple pairs of levels?

d4.tooltip: Different energy gaps produce different wavelengths.

sentences.text: Helium was discovered in the Sun's spectrum before being found on Earth. Scientists identified it because its {{d5}} pattern of emission lines matched no {{d6}} element.

d5.tooltip: Each element has its own spectral fingerprint.

d6.tooltip: The lines didn't match any previously identified elements.

absorption_spectra.title: Interpreting Absorption Spectra
absorption_spectra.instructions: Apply your understanding of absorption spectra to these scenarios.

sentences.text: The Sun's spectrum shows dark lines called Fraunhofer lines. These appear because atoms in the Sun's {{d1}} absorb specific wavelengths from the continuous spectrum produced by the {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Cooler gas absorbs light from the hot interior.

d2.tooltip: Where does the continuous spectrum originate?

sentences.text: When a photon is absorbed, its energy must {{d3}} match an energy gap in the atom. If the photon energy is wrong, it will {{d4}} through without being absorbed.

d3.tooltip: Quantised levels require exact energy matching.

d4.tooltip: What happens to photons that don't match any transition?

sentences.text: Astronomers identify elements in distant stars by analysing {{d5}} in their spectra. This technique works because spectral patterns are {{d6}} to each element.

d5.tooltip: What feature of spectra identifies elements?

d6.tooltip: Each element has its own pattern, like a fingerprint.

energy_levels.title: Mastering Energy Level Concepts
energy_levels.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of atomic energy levels.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that electrons can exist at any energy between levels. In reality, the regions between discrete energy levels are {{d1}} because an electron would {{d2}} with itself if it tried to orbit there.

d1.tooltip: What do we call energies that electrons cannot have?

d2.tooltip: Standing waves require what type of interference to form?

sentences.text: The ionisation energy of hydrogen is 13.6 eV, meaning a photon with {{d3}} this energy can remove the electron completely. Once ionised, the atom has {{d4}} bound electrons.

d3.tooltip: Must the photon have exactly the ionisation energy, or can it have more?

d4.tooltip: Ionisation removes the electron. How many remain?

sentences.text: When hydrogen has many excited atoms, electrons can transition to the ground state via {{d5}} paths. The n = 3 to n = 1 transition produces one photon, while n = 3 to n = 2 to n = 1 produces {{d6}} photons with different energies.

d5.tooltip: Can electrons take different routes down?

d6.tooltip: Count the transitions: n=3 to n=2 is one, n=2 to n=1 is another.

photon_energy.title: Mastering Photon Energy Calculations
photon_energy.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of photon energy relationships.

sentences.text: The threshold frequency for the photoelectric effect occurs when photon energy equals the {{d1}}. Below this frequency, electrons {{d2}} be ejected regardless of intensity.

d1.tooltip: What's the minimum energy needed to eject an electron from a metal?

d2.tooltip: If each photon lacks enough energy, can many photons combine?

sentences.text: X-ray photons have wavelengths around 10⁻¹⁰ m, while visible light has wavelengths around 10⁻⁷ m. X-rays have approximately {{d3}} times more energy because energy scales {{d4}} with wavelength.
A photon with λ = 400 nm (violet) has energy E₁ and a photon with λ = 800 nm (red) has energy E₂. The ratio E₁/E₂ equals {{d5}} because energy is {{d6}} proportional to wavelength.

d6.tooltip: E = hc/λ. If λ doubles, E halves.

emission_spectra.title: Advanced Emission Spectra Analysis
emission_spectra.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of emission spectra interpretation.

sentences.text: In a hydrogen discharge tube, the visible lines (Balmer series) all end at the {{d1}} level. The red line at 656 nm comes from n = 3, while the violet line at 410 nm comes from n = {{d2}}, which represents a larger energy transition.

d1.tooltip: The Balmer series involves transitions to which level?

d2.tooltip: Higher starting level = shorter wavelength = violet.

sentences.text: Metal vapour lamps produce more {{d3}} light than incandescent bulbs because they emit at {{d4}} wavelengths rather than wasting energy on infrared.

d3.tooltip: Concentrated output at useful wavelengths means less waste.

d4.tooltip: Line spectra vs continuous spectra for efficiency.

sentences.text: When a collection of excited hydrogen atoms emits light, the spectrum shows {{d5}} lines because many atoms make the same transitions {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Do many atoms produce new wavelengths or the same ones?

d6.tooltip: All hydrogen atoms have the same energy levels.

absorption_spectra.title: Advanced Absorption Spectra Analysis
absorption_spectra.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of absorption spectra interpretation.

sentences.text: The absorbed photons are re-emitted in {{d1}} directions, so the original beam appears to have those wavelengths {{d2}}. This creates the dark lines.

d1.tooltip: After absorption, the photon is re-emitted. In what direction?

d2.tooltip: If photons scatter in all directions, they're effectively...

sentences.text: A star's absorption spectrum reveals not only which {{d3}} are present but also their relative {{d4}}, since more atoms produce darker absorption lines.

d3.tooltip: What can we identify from spectral lines?

d4.tooltip: Darker lines indicate more absorption by more atoms.

sentences.text: The redshift of absorption lines from distant galaxies indicates they are {{d5}} from us. This is Doppler shift applied to {{d6}} waves.

d5.tooltip: Red shift means wavelengths are stretched. What motion causes this?

d6.tooltip: Light from stars is what type of wave?
